title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported one project maintainers. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct

what: 4 | What is the difference between a trait and a reported trait?
title: Frequently asked questions
text: two levels trait description GWAS Catalog: (EFO) trait reported trait. Studies assigned one terms Experimental Factor Ontology (EFO), .e., EFO trait, simply trait, best represents phenotype investigation. addition, study also assigned free text reported trait. written GWAS Catalog curators reflects author language, necessary, includes specific detailed description experimental design, e.g., interaction studies studies background trait. example take study accession identifier GCST000206 EM Behrens et al. (2008). can get EFO trait get_traits() reported trait get_studies(): (EFO) trait Behrens study chronic childhood arthritis: whereas reported trait Arthritis (juvenile idiopathic):
code: efo_trait <- get_traits(study_id = 'GCST000206') efo_trait@traits$trait #> [1] "juvenile idiopathic arthritis" study <- get_studies(study_id = 'GCST000206') study@studies$reported_trait #> [1] "Arthritis (juvenile idiopathic)"

what: 5 | Genomic coordinates of genomic contexts seem to be wrong?
title: Frequently asked questions
text: REST API response variants contains element named genomic contexts. element mapped onto table genomic_contexts variants S4 object. Now, indeed server-side bug column chromosome_position genomic_contexts table: chromosome position returned variant gene (genomic context) . GWAS Catalog team aware bug, plan fix , eventually. time , just rely chromosome_position genomic_contexts table.

previous_headings: 6 | How to search for variants within a certain genomic region?
title: Frequently asked questions
text: may use function get_variants() parameter genomic_range. example, search variants chromosome Y interval 14692000–14695000, start defining list 3 elements: chromosome, start end specify genomic range: Now can use my_genomic_range retrieve variants:
code: # 'chromosome' names are case sensitive, and should be uppercase. # 'start' and 'end' positions should be integer vectors. my_genomic_range <- list(   chromosome = 'Y',   start = 14692000L,   end = 14695000L) chr_Y_variants <- get_variants(genomic_range = my_genomic_range) chr_Y_variants@variants[c('variant_id', 'functional_class')] #> # A tibble: 1 × 2 #>   variant_id functional_class #>   <chr>      <chr>            #> 1 rs2115848  intron_variant

previous_headings: 6 | How to search for variants within a certain genomic region?
title: Frequently asked questions
text: search multiple regions, construct genomic range list locations just like previous example. example, let’s search now variants chromosome X Y, range 13000000–15000000:
code: my_genomic_range <- list(   chromosome = c('X', 'Y'),   start = c(13000000L, 13000000L),   end = c(15000000L, 15000000L))  chr_XY_variants <- get_variants(genomic_range = my_genomic_range) chr_XY_variants@variants[c('variant_id',                            'chromosome_name',                            'chromosome_position')] #> # A tibble: 24 × 3 #>    variant_id  chromosome_name chromosome_position #>    <chr>       <chr>                         <int> #>  1 rs111689944 X                          13494655 #>  2 rs7063195   X                          13492087 #>  3 rs5978649   X                          13596999 #>  4 rs5934106   X                          13488259 #>  5 rs749624882 X                          14929148 #>  6 rs61273829  X                          14150876 #>  7 rs6528024   X                          13912803 #>  8 rs66819623  X                          13936278 #>  9 rs138331350 X                          14841981 #> 10 rs5980075   X                          14932409 #> # … with 14 more rows

title: Frequently asked questions
text: search variants within cytogenetic band can use parameter cytogenetic_band get_variants(). example, chromosome Y, using cytogenetic band 'Yq11.221' query: know cytogenetic bands querying? provide dataset (dataframe) named cytogenetic_bands can use: Let’s say want search variants shorter arm (p) chromosome 21, can take advantage cytogenetic_bands get corresponding cytogenetic band names: Now search cytogenetic_band:
code: my_variants <- get_variants(cytogenetic_band = 'Yq11.221') my_variants@variants[c('variant_id',                        'chromosome_name',                        'chromosome_position')] #> # A tibble: 3 × 3 #>   variant_id chromosome_name chromosome_position #>   <chr>      <chr>                         <int> #> 1 rs2032624  Y                          12914512 #> 2 rs2115848  Y                          14692972 #> 3 rs2032658  Y                          13470103 # ?cytogenetic_bands for more details. cytogenetic_bands #> # A tibble: 862 × 8 #>    cytogenetic_band chromosome    start      end  length assembly stain  last_download_date       #>    <chr>            <chr>         <int>    <int>   <dbl> <chr>    <chr>  <chr>                    #>  1 1p36.33          1                 1  2300000 2300000 GRCh38   gneg   Thu Jun 27 15:09:22 2019 #>  2 1p36.32          1           2300001  5300000 3000000 GRCh38   gpos25 Thu Jun 27 15:09:22 2019 #>  3 1p36.31          1           5300001  7100000 1800000 GRCh38   gneg   Thu Jun 27 15:09:22 2019 #>  4 1p36.23          1           7100001  9100000 2000000 GRCh38   gpos25 Thu Jun 27 15:09:22 2019 #>  5 1p36.22          1           9100001 12500000 3400000 GRCh38   gneg   Thu Jun 27 15:09:22 2019 #>  6 1p36.21          1          12500001 15900000 3400000 GRCh38   gpos50 Thu Jun 27 15:09:22 2019 #>  7 1p36.13          1          15900001 20100000 4200000 GRCh38   gneg   Thu Jun 27 15:09:22 2019 #>  8 1p36.12          1          20100001 23600000 3500000 GRCh38   gpos25 Thu Jun 27 15:09:22 2019 #>  9 1p36.11          1          23600001 27600000 4000000 GRCh38   gneg   Thu Jun 27 15:09:22 2019 #> 10 1p35.3           1          27600001 29900000 2300000 GRCh38   gpos25 Thu Jun 27 15:09:22 2019 #> # … with 852 more rows # Install package dplyr if you do not have it. chr21_p_bands <- dplyr::filter(cytogenetic_bands, grepl('^21p', cytogenetic_band)) %>%   dplyr::pull(cytogenetic_band) chr21_p_bands #> [1] "21p13"   "21p12"   "21p11.2" "21p11.1" my_variants <- get_variants(cytogenetic_band = chr21_p_bands) my_variants@variants[c('variant_id',                        'chromosome_name',                        'chromosome_position',                        'chromosome_region')] #> # A tibble: 4 × 4 #>   variant_id  chromosome_name chromosome_position chromosome_region #>   <chr>       <chr>                         <int> <chr>             #> 1 rs552964654 21                          9053097 21p11.2           #> 2 rs10439884  21                         10540506 21p11.2           #> 3 rs75275574  21                          9040338 21p11.2           #> 4 rs240444    21                         10510446 21p11.2

what: 7 | Genomic range for an entire chromosome?
title: Frequently asked questions
text: can get total length chromosome using provided data set: cytogenetic_bands. example chromosome 15:
code: # Install dplyr first. dplyr::filter(cytogenetic_bands, chromosome == '15') %>%   dplyr::summarise(chromosome = dplyr::first(chromosome),                    start = min(start),                    end = max(end)                    ) #> # A tibble: 1 × 3 #>   chromosome start       end #>   <chr>      <int>     <int> #> 1 15             1 101991189

what: 8 | How to keep track of which queries generated which results?
title: Frequently asked questions
text: Currently, implemented solution gwasrapidd. example, search variants EFO identifier (efo_id): immediately obvious variants resulted query 'EFO_0005543' 'EFO_0004762'. possible workaround make multiple independent queries save results list whose names respective queries: Now can see variants associated EFO identifier. 'EFO_0005543' got following variants: 'EFO_0004762':

what: 9 | How to combine results from multiple queries?
title: Frequently asked questions
text: four main retrieval functions get_studies(), get_associations(), get_variants() get_traits() allow search multiple criteria . can combine results fashion using parameter set_operation. Use set_operation = 'union' combine results fashion: code retrieves variants whose associated efo_trait equal 'triple-negative breast cancer' variants associated gene 'MDM4'. Alternatively, may use set_operation = 'intersection' combine results fashion: set_operation = 'intersection', code , get variants whose associated efo_trait equal 'triple-negative breast cancer' associated gene 'MDM4', .e., variants meeting conditions simultaneously retrieved. Please note almost search criteria used retrieval functions vectorised, meaning can use multiple values search criterion. cases results always combined fashion. following example, using gene name search criterion. pass vector gene names get variants associated EITHER () genes. case retrieved 33 variants. Please note set_operation parameter affect result. set_operation controls function behaviour combining results different criteria, e.g., using efo_trait gene_name. retrieve variants concomitantly associated genes RNU6-367P ABHD5, user needs place queries separately intersect — using intersect() function, .e., combining fashion. start retrieving variants associated gene RNU6-367P: 19 variants associated gene RNU6-367P. Now, gene ABHD5: 23 variants associated gene ABHD5. find variants simultaneously associated genes, can intersect two variants objects using gwasrapidd::intersect(): Apparently 9 variant(s) related genes RNU6-367P ABHD5.

title: Getting started with gwasrapidd
text: GWAS Catalog service provided EMBL-EBI NHGRI offers manually curated freely available database published genome-wide association studies (GWAS). Catalog website infrastructure hosted EMBL-EBI. gwasrapidd facilitates access Catalog via REST API, allowing programmatically retrieve data directly R.

title: Getting started with gwasrapidd
text: Catalog REST API organized around four core entities: studies associations variants traits gwasrapidd provides four corresponding functions get entities: get_studies(), get_associations(), get_variants(), get_traits(). function maps appropriately named S4 classed object: studies, associations, variants, traits (see Figure 1). Figure 1: gwasrapidd retrieval functions. can use combination several search criteria retrieval function shown Figure 2. example, want get studies using either one two criteria: study accession identifier (study_id) variant identifier (variant_id) run following code: command returns studies match either 'GCST000858' 'rs12752552'. equivalent running get_studies separately criteria, combining results afterwards: four retrieval functions accept set_operation parameter defines way results obtained criterion combined. two options parameter 'union' (default) 'intersection', resulting, respectively, operation. Figure 2: gwasrapidd arguments retrieval functions. Colors indicate criteria can used retrieving GWAS Catalog entities: studies (green), associations (red), variants (purple), traits (orange).
code: library(gwasrapidd)  my_studies <- get_studies(study_id = 'GCST000858', variant_id = 'rs12752552') my_studies@studies s1 <- get_studies(study_id = 'GCST000858') s2 <- get_studies(variant_id = 'rs12752552') my_studies <- gwasrapidd::union(s1, s2)

what: Finding Risk Alleles Associated with Autoimmune Disease
title: Getting started with gwasrapidd
text: first example, take work Light et al. (2014). work authors focused variants previously reported genome-wide association studies (GWAS) autoimmune disease. gwasrapidd can interrogate GWAS Catalog study/studies searching autoimmune disease (EFO trait). let’s load gwasrapidd first: query GWAS Catalog EFO trait: can now check many GWAS studies got back: Apparently 9 studies: GCST003097, GCST011008, GCST007071, GCST009873, GCST011005, GCST011009, GCST90029015, GCST90029016, GCST90012738. Let’s see associated publication titles: want inspect publications, can quickly browse respective PubMed entries: Now want know variants previously associated autoimmune disease, used Light et al. (2014), need retrieve statistical association information variants, filter based level significance \(P < 1\times 10^{-6}\) (Light et al. 2014). let’s start getting associations study_id: Seemingly, 182 associations. However, variants meet level significance, required Light et al. (2014): subset my_associations object vector association identifiers (association_ids) smaller object, my_associations2: 182 associations found GWAS Catalog, 180 meet p-value threshold \(1\times 10^{-6}\). variants, respective risk allele risk frequency:
code: library(gwasrapidd) my_studies <- get_studies(efo_trait = 'autoimmune disease') gwasrapidd::n(my_studies) #> [1] 9 my_studies@studies$study_id #> [1] "GCST003097"   "GCST011008"   "GCST007071"   "GCST009873"   "GCST011005"   "GCST011009"   "GCST90029015" #> [8] "GCST90029016" "GCST90012738" my_studies@publications$title #> [1] "Meta-analysis of shared genetic architecture across ten pediatric autoimmune diseases."                                                             #> [2] "Genetic factors underlying the bidirectional relationship between autoimmune and mental disorders - findings from a Danish population-based study." #> [3] "Leveraging Polygenic Functional Enrichment to Improve GWAS Power."                                                                                  #> [4] "Meta-analysis of Immunochip data of four autoimmune diseases reveals novel single-disease and cross-phenotype associations."                        #> [5] "Genetic factors underlying the bidirectional relationship between autoimmune and mental disorders - findings from a Danish population-based study." #> [6] "Genetic factors underlying the bidirectional relationship between autoimmune and mental disorders - findings from a Danish population-based study." #> [7] "Mixed-model association for biobank-scale datasets."                                                                                                #> [8] "Mixed-model association for biobank-scale datasets."                                                                                                #> [9] "Clinical laboratory test-wide association scan of polygenic scores identifies biomarkers of complex disease." # This launches your web browser at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26301688 open_in_pubmed(my_studies@publications$pubmed_id) # You could have also used get_associations(efo_trait = 'autoimmune disease') my_associations <- get_associations(study_id = my_studies@studies$study_id) gwasrapidd::n(my_associations) #> [1] 182 # Get association ids for which pvalue is less than 1e-6. dplyr::filter(my_associations@associations, pvalue < 1e-6) %>% # Filter by p-value   tidyr::drop_na(pvalue) %>%   dplyr::pull(association_id) -> association_ids # Extract column association_id # Extract associations by association id my_associations2 <- my_associations[association_ids] gwasrapidd::n(my_associations2) #> [1] 180 my_associations2@risk_alleles[c('variant_id', 'risk_allele', 'risk_frequency')] #> # A tibble: 180 × 3 #>    variant_id risk_allele risk_frequency #>    <chr>      <chr>                <dbl> #>  1 rs11580078 G                     0.43 #>  2 rs6679677  A                     0.09 #>  3 rs34884278 C                     0.3  #>  4 rs6689858  C                     0.29 #>  5 rs2075184  T                     0.23 #>  6 rs36001488 C                     0.48 #>  7 rs4676410  A                     0.19 #>  8 rs4625     G                     0.31 #>  9 rs62324212 A                     0.42 #> 10 rs7725052  C                     0.43 #> # … with 170 more rows

title: REST API Client for the NHGRI-EBI GWAS Catalog
text: Get studies related triple-negative breast cancer: Find associated variants study GCST002305:
code: library(gwasrapidd) studies <- get_studies(efo_trait = 'triple-negative breast cancer') studies@studies[1:4] ## # A tibble: 3 × 4 ##   study_id     reported_trait         initial_sample_size replication_sample_s…¹ ##   <chr>        <chr>                  <chr>               <chr>                  ## 1 GCST002305   Breast cancer (estrog… 1,529 European anc… 2,148 European ancest… ## 2 GCST010100   Breast cancer (estrog… 8,602 European anc… <NA>                   ## 3 GCST90029052 15-year breast cancer… 5,631 European anc… <NA>                   ## # ℹ abbreviated name: ¹​replication_sample_size variants <- get_variants(study_id = 'GCST002305') variants@variants[c('variant_id', 'functional_class')] ## # A tibble: 5 × 2 ##   variant_id functional_class    ##   <chr>      <chr>               ## 1 rs4245739  3_prime_UTR_variant ## 2 rs2363956  missense_variant    ## 3 rs10069690 intron_variant      ## 4 rs3757318  intron_variant      ## 5 rs10771399 intergenic_variant

what: An S4 class to represent a set of GWAS Catalog associations — associations-class
title: An S4 class to represent a set of GWAS Catalog associations — associations-class
text: association object consists six slots, table (tibble), combined form relational database subset GWAS Catalog associations. association observation (row) associations table --- main table. tables column association_id primary key.

title: An S4 class to represent a set of GWAS Catalog associations — associations-class
text: associations tibble listing associations.   Columns: association_id GWAS Catalog association accession identifier, e.g., "20250". pvalue Reported p-value strongest variant risk effect allele. pvalue_description Information describing context p-value. pvalue_mantissa Mantissa p-value. pvalue_exponent Exponent p-value. multiple_snp_haplotype Whether association multi-SNP haplotype. snp_interaction Whether association SNP-SNP interaction. snp_type Whether SNP previously reported. Either 'known' 'novel'. risk_frequency Reported risk/effect allele frequency associated strongest SNP controls. standard_error Standard error effect size. range Reported 95% confidence interval associated strongest SNP risk allele, along unit case beta coefficients. 95% CIs reported, estimated using standard error, available. or_per_copy_number Reported odds ratio () associated strongest SNP risk allele. Note ORs included Catalog >1. beta_number Beta coefficient associated strongest SNP risk allele. beta_unit Beta coefficient unit. beta_direction Beta coefficient direction, either 'decrease' 'increase'. beta_description Additional beta coefficient comment. last_mapping_date Last time association mapped Ensembl. last_update_date Last time association updated. loci tibble listing loci. Columns: association_id GWAS Catalog association accession identifier, e.g., "20250". locus_id locus identifier referring single variant locus multi-loci entity multi-SNP haplotype. haplotype_snp_count Number variants per locus. loci single-SNP loci, .e., one one relationship variant locus_id (haplotype_snp_count == NA). however cases associations involving multiple loci , SNP-SNP interactions multi-SNP haplotypes. signalled columns: multiple_snp_haplotype snp_interaction value TRUE. description Description locus identifier, e.g., 'Single variant', SNP x SNP interaction, 3-SNP Haplotype. risk_alleles tibble listing risk alleles.   Columns: association_id GWAS Catalog association accession identifier, e.g., "20250". locus_id locus identifier referring single variant locus multi-loci entity multi-SNP haplotype. variant_id Variant identifier, e.g., 'rs1333048'. risk_allele Risk allele effect allele. risk_frequency Reported risk/effect allele frequency associated strongest SNP controls (available among controls, among control group largest sample size). associated locus haplotype haplotype frequency extracted. genome_wide Whether variant allele part genome-wide study . limited_list Undocumented. genes tibble listing author reported genes.   Columns: association_id GWAS Catalog association accession identifier, e.g., "20250". locus_id locus identifier referring single variant locus multi-loci entity multi-SNP haplotype. gene_name Gene symbol according HUGO Gene Nomenclature (HGNC). ensembl_ids tibble listing Ensembl gene   identifiers. Columns: association_id GWAS Catalog association accession identifier, e.g., "20250". locus_id locus identifier referring single variant locus multi-loci entity multi-SNP haplotype. gene_name Gene symbol according HUGO Gene Nomenclature (HGNC). ensembl_id Ensembl identifier Ensembl gene, see Section Gene annotation Ensembl information. entrez_ids tibble listing Entrez gene   identifiers. Columns: association_id GWAS Catalog association accession identifier, e.g., "20250". locus_id locus identifier referring single variant locus multi-loci entity multi-SNP haplotype. gene_name Gene symbol according HUGO Gene Nomenclature (HGNC). entrez_id Entrez identifier gene, see ref. doi:10.1093/nar/gkq1237  information.

text: data frame 862 rows 8 variables: cytogenetic_band Cytogenetic band name. See Cytogenetic   Nomenclature . chromosome Chromosome name: 1 22 (autosomes), X   Y. start Genomic start position cytogenetic band. Starts 1. end Genomic end position cytogenetic band. End position   included band interval. length Length genomic interval cytogenetic band. assembly Assembly version, 'GRCh38'. stain Giemsa   stain results: Giemsa negative, 'gneg'; Giemsa positive,   increasing intensities, 'gpos25', 'gpos50', 'gpos75',   'gpos100'; centromeric region, 'acen'; heterochromatin,   either pericentric telomeric, 'gvar'; short arm   acrocentric chromosomes 13, 14, 15, 21, 22 coded   'stalk'. last_download_date Time stamp last time dataset   downloaded Ensembl.

title: GRCh38 human cytogenetic bands. — cytogenetic_bands
text: Genomic coordinates fully closed intervals.

title: GRCh38 human cytogenetic bands. — cytogenetic_bands
text: Cytogenetic bands numbered centromere outwards directions towards telomeres shorter p arm longer q arm. first number letter represents chromosome. Chromosomes 1 22 (autosomes) designated chromosome number. sex chromosomes designated X Y. next letter represents arm chromosome: p q. numbers read normal decimal numeric system e.g. 36, rather 3-6 (region 3 band 6). Counting starts centromere region 1 (1-0), 11 (1-1) 21 (2-1) 22 (2-2) etc. Subbands added similar way, e.g. 21.1 21.2, bands small appear higher resolution.

title: Get GWAS Catalog variants — get_variants
text: study_id character vector GWAS Catalog study accession identifiers. association_id character vector GWAS Catalog association identifiers. variant_id character vector GWAS Catalog variant identifiers. efo_id character vector EFO identifiers. pubmed_id integer vector PubMed identifiers. genomic_range named list three vectors: chromosome character vector chromosome names form 1--22, X Y. start numeric vector start positions, starting 1. end numeric vector end positions. three vectors need length chromosome names, start end positions can matched position. cytogenetic_band character vector cytogenetic bands form '1p36.11'. gene_name Gene symbol according HUGO Gene Nomenclature (HGNC). efo_trait character vector EFO trait descriptions, e.g., 'uric acid measurement'. reported_trait character vector phenotypic traits reported original authors study. set_operation Either 'union' 'intersection'. tells variants retrieved different criteria  combined: 'union' binds together results removing duplicates 'intersection' keeps variants found different criteria. interactive logical. variants requested, whether ask interactively really want proceed. std_chromosomes_only Whether return variants mapped standard chromosomes: 1 thru 22, X, Y, MT. verbose Whether function verbose different queries . warnings Whether print warnings.

title: Get GWAS Catalog variants — get_variants
text: variants object.

title: Get GWAS Catalog variants — get_variants
text: Please note search criteria vectorised, thus allowing batch mode search, e.g., one can search multiple variant identifiers passing vector identifiers variant_id.

Yes. #> Is there a DNS service running? Yes. #> Connected to the internet? Yes. #> Ping'ing www.ebi.ac.uk on port 443... #> www.ebi.ac.uk successfully replied in 135.105 ms. #> [1] TRUE

title: Normalise a JSON-list. — normalise_obj
text: function normalises JSON-list. concept JSON-list defined ordinary R list object whose elements either named none named. lists map naturally JSON elements: objects arrays. function wrap certain elements nested list obj list() make tree structure obj list homologous across different responses. makes responses entity type (studies, associations, variants traits) homologous hence joinable family functions lst_*_join.

title: Normalise a JSON-list. — normalise_obj
code: normalise_obj(obj, resource_url)

title: Normalise a JSON-list. — normalise_obj
text: obj JSON-list. just ordinary list returned gc_request gc_request_all. resource_url URL endpoint used obtain JSON-list obj. used infer type GWAS entity returned. See object_type_from_url details.

title: Normalise a JSON-list. — normalise_obj
text: normalised JSON-list.

title: Normalise a JSON-list. — normalise_obj
text: normalisation GWAS object type specific. parameter resource_url mappable either studies, associations, variants traits object_type_from_url.

what: Browse GWAS Catalog entities from the GWAS Web Graphical User Interface — open_in_gwas_catalog
title: Browse GWAS Catalog entities from the GWAS Web Graphical User Interface — open_in_gwas_catalog
text: function launches web browser opens tab identifier GWAS web graphical user interface: https://www.ebi.ac.uk/gwas.

title: Browse GWAS Catalog entities from the GWAS Web Graphical User Interface — open_in_gwas_catalog
code: open_in_gwas_catalog(   identifier,   gwas_catalog_entity = c("study", "variant", "trait", "gene", "region", "publication") )

title: Browse GWAS Catalog entities from the GWAS Web Graphical User Interface — open_in_gwas_catalog
text: identifier vector identifiers. identifiers can : study accession identifiers, variant identifiers, EFO trait identifiers, gene symbol names, cytogenetic regions, PubMed identifiers. gwas_catalog_entity Either 'study' (default), 'variant', 'trait', 'gene', 'region' 'publication', scalar character. argument indicates type identifiers passed identifier.

title: Browse GWAS Catalog entities from the GWAS Web Graphical User Interface — open_in_gwas_catalog
text: Returns TRUE successful, FALSE otherwise.   note function run side effect.

title: Browse GWAS Catalog entities from the GWAS Web Graphical User Interface — open_in_gwas_catalog
code: # Open studies in GWAS Web Graphical User Interface open_in_gwas_catalog(c('GCST000016', 'GCST001115'))  # Open variants open_in_gwas_catalog(c('rs146992477', 'rs56261590'),   gwas_catalog_entity = 'variant')  # Open EFO traits open_in_gwas_catalog(c('EFO_0004884', 'EFO_0004343'),   gwas_catalog_entity = 'trait')  # Open genes open_in_gwas_catalog(c('DPP6', 'MCCC2'),   gwas_catalog_entity = 'gene')  # Open cytogenetic regions open_in_gwas_catalog(c('2q37.1', '1p36.11'),   gwas_catalog_entity = 'region')  # Open publications open_in_gwas_catalog(c('25533513', '24376627'),   gwas_catalog_entity = 'publication')

text: function checks value TEST_FAST, 'true' skips test otherwise still runs following expectations. Please note function used gwasrapidd development.

code: skip_if_testing_is_fast()

title: Skips a test if TEST_FAST is 'true' — skip_if_testing_is_fast
text: Returns TRUE environment variable 'TEST_FAST'   set 'false', return anything triggers side   effect skipping next test (testthat).

what: An S4 class to represent a set of GWAS Catalog studies — studies-class
title: An S4 class to represent a set of GWAS Catalog studies — studies-class
text: studies object consists eight slots, table (tibble), combined form relational database subset GWAS Catalog studies. study observation (row) studies table --- main table. tables column study_id primary key.

title: An S4 class to represent a set of GWAS Catalog studies — studies-class
text: studies study_id GWAS Catalog study accession identifier, e.g., "GCST002735". reported_trait Phenotypic trait reported authors study, e.g. "Breast cancer". initial_sample_size Free text description initial cohort sample size. replication_sample_size Free text description replication cohort sample size. gxe Whether study investigates gene-environment interaction. gxg Whether study investigates gene-gene interaction. snp_count Number variants passing quality control. qualifier Qualifier number variants passing quality control. imputed Whether variants imputed. pooled Whether samples pooled. study_design_comment relevant study design information. full_pvalue_set Whether full summary statistics available study. user_requested Whether addition study GWAS Catalog requested user. genotyping_techs tibble listing genotyping   technologies employed study. Columns: study_id GWAS Catalog study accession identifier. genotyping_technology Genotyping technology employed, e.g. "Exome genotyping array", "Exome-wide sequencing", "Genome-wide genotyping array", "Genome-wide sequencing", "Targeted genotyping array". platforms tibble listing platforms used per   study. study_id GWAS Catalog study accession identifier. manufacturer Platform manufacturer, e.g., "Affymetrix", "Illumina", "Perlegen". ancestries tibble listing ancestry samples   used study. study_id GWAS Catalog study accession identifier. ancestry_id Ancestry identifier. type Stage ancestry sample: either 'initial' 'replication'. number_of_individuals Number individuals comprising ancestry sample. ancestral_groups tibble listing ancestral   groups used ancestry. study_id GWAS Catalog study accession identifier. ancestry_id Ancestry identifier. ancestral_group Genetic ancestry groups present sample. countries_of_origin tibble listing countries   origin samples. study_id GWAS Catalog study accession identifier. ancestry_id Ancestry identifier. country_name Country name, according United Nations M49 Standard Geographic Regions. major_area Region name, according United Nations M49 Standard Geographic Regions. region Sub-region name, according United Nations M49 Standard Geographic Regions. countries_of_recruitment tibble listing   countries recruitment samples. study_id GWAS Catalog study accession identifier. ancestry_id Ancestry identifier. country_name Country name, according United Nations M49 Standard Geographic Regions. major_area Region name, according United Nations M49 Standard Geographic Regions. region Sub-region name, according United Nations M49 Standard Geographic Regions. publications tibble listing publications   associated study. study_id GWAS Catalog study accession identifier. pubmed_id PubMed identifier. publication_date Publication date (online date available) formatted ymd. publication Abbreviated journal name. title Publication title. author_fullname Last name initials first author. author_orcid Author's ORCID iD (Open Researcher Contributor ID).

title: An S4 class to represent a set of GWAS Catalog variants — variants-class
text: variants tibble listing variants. Columns: variant_id Variant identifier, e.g., 'rs1333048'. merged Whether SNP merged another SNP newer genome build. functional_class Class according Ensembl's predicted consequences variant allele may transcripts. See Ensembl Variation - Calculated variant consequences. chromosome_name Chromosome name. chromosome_position Chromosome position. chromosome_region Cytogenetic location. last_update_date Last time variant updated. genomic_contexts tibble listing genomic   contexts associated variant. Columns: variant_id Variant identifier. gene_name Gene symbol according HUGO Gene Nomenclature (HGNC). chromosome_name Chromosome name. chromosome_position Chromosome position. distance Genomic distance variant gene (base pairs). is_mapped_gene Whether mapped gene variant. mapped gene either overlapping gene variant two closest genes upstream downstream variant. Moreover, genes whose mapping source 'Ensembl' considered. is_closest_gene Whether closest gene variant. is_intergenic Whether variant intergenic, .e, gene downstream within 100kb. is_upstream Whether variant upstream gene. is_downstream Whether variant downstream gene. source Gene mapping source, either Ensembl NCBI. mapping_method Gene mapping method. ensembl_ids tibble listing gene Ensembl   identifiers associated genomic context. Columns: variant_id Variant identifier. gene_name Gene symbol according HUGO Gene Nomenclature (HGNC). ensembl_id Ensembl identifier Ensembl gene, see Section Gene annotation Ensembl information. entrez_ids tibble listing gene Entrez   identifiers associated genomic context. Columns: variant_id Variant identifier. gene_name Gene symbol according HUGO Gene Nomenclature (HGNC). entrez_id Entrez identifier gene, see ref. doi:10.1093/nar/gkq1237  information.
